newsitem.title: USA: Debt, equity underwriting over $273 bln in Q1 -SDC.
newsitem.headline: Debt, equity underwriting over $273 bln in Q1 -SDC.

text.p: U.S. stock and bond underwriting rose during the first quarter, with overall issuance of domestic debt and equity exceeding $273 billion compared to $244.9 billion in the year-ago quarter, according to Securities Data Co.

Merrill Lynch was the leading underwriter of domestic debt and equity in the first quarter, Securities Data said. The firm took a 16 percent share of the domestic public underwriting business in the first quarter, responsible 312 issues with total proceeds of $44.4 billion, it said.

Goldman, Sachs ranked second, after lead-managing $33.2 billion in debt and equity from 290 issues this quarter, while Salomon Brothers had the third highest level of underwritings, with over $29.8 billion, Securities Data said.
Straight debt issuance rose but common stock and initial public offerings fell, the company said.
Straight debt issuance rose more than 20 percent in the quarter, compared to year-ago period, Securities Data said.
In this area, Merrill Lynch was the lead manager with $22.4 billion from 111 deals in the quarter. J.P. Morgan placed second with over $21 billion from 167 issues.
Domestic corporate bond high-yield debt issuance exceeded $8.2 billion in the current quarter, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette was the leading underwriter, it said.
But common stock underwriting fell seven percent to $21.2 billion from 303 deals in the first quarter, compared to nearly $23 billion on 328 issues in the year-ago first quarter, the company said.
Merrill Lynch, which ranked fifth in equity underwriting during the first quarter of 1996, led the rest in this area during 1997's first quarter, it said.
The firm was responsible for $3.65 billion in activity from 29 deals, Securities Data said.

IPO issuance declined by more than 30 percent from the first-quarter 1996 levels, to $5.9 billion from $8.26 billion, it said. Securities Data said this was the lowest level since the first quarter of 1995.
The average size of the deal also fell by more than 11 percent to $43 million from a year ago, it said.
Morgan Stanley was the first in IPO issuance with $886 million from 10 deals, it said.

Merrill Lynch also posted the most disclosed fees in the first quarter, generating $336.4 million from 312 issues, it said. This compared to the firm's $261 million in fees in last year's quarter from 289 deals.
